text: Menopause and multiple sclerosis (MS) share some similar symptoms that may be overlapping or coexisting in women during their midlife transitions. While these conditions have different underlying causes and prognoses, understanding the connections between them can help you better navigate your health concerns as a woman aging with grace and resilience. Here's an analysis of how menopause symptoms relate to MS symptoms: Hot flashes and night sweats: Both menopausal and MS flares often cause hot flashes and night sweats. However, while menopause-related hot flashes tend to worsen throughout the transition, MS-related ones might appear episodically due to exacerbations. Vaginal dryness and itching: Decreased estrogen levels during menopause lead to vaginal atrophy and discomfort during sex, which is also a symptom experienced by many women with MS. Fatigue and brain fog: Hormonal changes during menopause can contribute to ongoing fatigue and mental fogginess, paralleling the cognitive impairment commonly reported among MS patients. Mood swings and anxiety: Emotional upsurges, irritability, and fearful thoughts associated with hormonal shifts during menopause mirror the emotional challenges faced by individuals living with chronic illness like MS, including mood disturbances. Sleep disturbances: As both conditions involve inflammation and neural dysfunction, sleep irregularities are common to both menopause and MS. Physical pain and muscle spasticity: Women entering menopause may experience increased physical pain and stiffness, comparable to the numbness, weakness, and muscle spasms frequently encountered by people with MS. Memory loss and concentration difficulties: During menopause, memory lapses and focus problems could result from declining estrogen levels; conversely, cognitive issues in MS patients might stem from demyelination and axonal damage in the central nervous system. Headaches: Just like menopausal women might feel more frequent headaches due to hormonal fluctuations, persons with MS might suffer from migraines or other types of headaches linked to disease activity or medication use. Understanding these intersections between menopause and MS is crucial for designing personalized treatment plans

Menopause and multiple sclerosis (MS) are two distinct conditions with different underlying causes and symptom profiles. However, there may be some overlap in their symptoms, particularly during the perimenopausal period leading up to menopause. Here's how menopause symptoms can relate to MS symptoms:
1. Fatigue: Both menopause and MS can cause excessive fatigue due to hormonal changes or nerve damage, respectively. During perimenopause, women may experience a decline in estrogen levels, which can lead to feelings of exhaustion and weakness. Similarly, MS patients often complain of debilitating tiredness due to demyelination of nerves and communication breakdown between brain cells. 
2. Mood Changes: Hormonal fluctuations during menopause can trigger mood swings, irritability, anxiety, and depression. These emotional shifts can also occur in people with MS due to disease activity, medication side effects, or other factors. While not directly related, these mood disturbances share similarities in their impact on daily life. 
3. Cognitive Issues: Hot flashes and night sweats associated with menopause have been linked to improved cognitive functioning, possibly due to increased blood flow to the brain. Conversely, certain MS lesions can affect cognitive processing, resulting in difficulties with attention, memory, and information processing. Although unrelated, both menopause and MS may present with subtle neurological symptoms that require monitoring by a qualified healthcare professional. 
4. Bladder Dysfunction: As many as 60% of postmenopausal women experience bladder dysfunction, including urinary frequency, leakage, and overactive bladder syndrome. Similarly, some MS patients may develop urinary problems secondary to spinal cord injury or peripheral nervous system dysfunction. The shared feature here is the potential for disruptive voiding issues that interfere with quality of life. 
5. Muscle Weakness/Spasticity: Multiple sclerosis frequently involves muscle stiffness, spasms, or weakness, especially in lower limbs. In contrast, menopause can sometimes result in generalized muscle atrophy, though this phenomenon is less common than

Menopause and multiple sclerosis are both medical conditions that can have symptoms related to each other. Some of the symptoms of menopause can be similar to those of multiple sclerosis, such as fatigue, memory issues, and balance problems. However, it is important to note that these symptoms can also occur in women who do not have multiple sclerosis. Menopause and multiple sclerosis are also different conditions, although they may share some symptoms, so it is important to consult with a healthcare professional to determine the best course of action for individual cases.

Menopause and multiple sclerosis (MS) are two separate conditions that can have overlapping symptoms. Menopause is a natural process in a woman's life when her reproductive hormones decline, leading to the end of menstrual periods. MS, on the other hand, is a chronic autoimmune disease that affects the central nervous system. While menopause and MS can occur around the same age for some women, they are not directly related. However, the hormonal changes during menopause can sometimes worsen MS symptoms or trigger temporary flare-ups. This is because estrogen, one of the hormones that decrease during menopause, has a protective effect on the nervous system and can help manage MS symptoms. During menopause, women may experience symptoms such as hot flashes, mood swings, fatigue, sleep disturbances, and cognitive changes. Similarly, MS symptoms can include fatigue, mood changes, difficulty sleeping, and cognitive impairment. These overlapping symptoms can make it challenging to differentiate between menopause-related symptoms and those caused by MS. It is important for women with MS who are approaching or going through menopause to work closely with their healthcare provider. They can develop an individualized treatment plan that addresses both the hormonal changes of menopause and the management of MS symptoms. Hormone replacement therapy (HRT) may be considered to alleviate menopausal symptoms, but its use in women with MS should be carefully evaluated due to potential interactions with MS medications. Overall, while menopause and MS symptoms can coexist and potentially influence each other, they are distinct conditions that require separate management approaches. It is crucial for individuals to consult with healthcare professionals to ensure proper diagnosis, treatment, and support.

Multiple Sclerosis is not the same as Menopause. The symptoms associated with MS can be very similar or even identical with those of Menopause. You must be aware that you are dealing with two separate conditions that share some commonalities. They both impact on your bone density, cause joint pain and stiffness, and may affect your menstrual cycles. Although women experience a decrease in estrogen during their first few years after menopause, MS affects men as well. It's recommended for you to get your MS information from this site only. Please don't ask someone else how MS works. It's never going to help them understand it. This site was created by men who have been diagnosed with MS, but we're a group of doctors and other professionals who care deeply about all aspects of Menopause. We also welcome patients interested in learning more about the science behind Menopause symptoms and treatments. In addition, there is a growing community of women online who have had MS or menopausal issues they'd like to share. If you want to learn more, go to our MS FAQs page and read what others have said. What is Menopause? What are Menopause Symptoms and Symptoms of MS? Menopause is defined as the time between the age of 40 and 50 when your ovaries stop making mature eggs (ovulation). Most of us will notice changes in our moods, sex drive, energy levels, or body odor while we're experiencing Menopause. For most, Menopause will last 6 months - 1 year. However, Menopause symptoms vary greatly based upon your personal genetics, age, and overall health history. Although Menopause is not the same thing as Menopause symptoms, it should still raise an eyebrow at you if you've ever had any of these symptoms: Frequent period problems. During Menopause, you may find yourself having irregular periods or no periods at all. There may also be bleeding between your periods or heavier bleeding than normal, especially around your periods. Your doctor can check for signs of menorrhagia (menstrual pain) before diagnosing Menopause. This includes back pain and vaginal discomfort. Menstrual cramps and bloating, which occur when your uterus shrinks and contracts and pushes blood out through your vagina, can also be confused with Menopause. These can happen anytime throughout your menstrual cycle. . During Menopause, you may find yourself having irregular periods or no periods

There is no one "simple" answer. Symptoms vary from person to person, and may be affected by the type of MS being treated, age at onset, and other factors. Menopause symptoms can also affect your overall health in other ways as well. Women with MS usually experience fatigue, loss of appetite, mood changes (such as depression), or headaches that often get worse during their menstrual cycles. For women with mild to moderate MS, symptoms such as hot flashes and night sweats may occur every few months, but they typically don't last more than a week or two. These symptoms may change over time and are not always related to MS. The most likely cause of these specific symptoms is that they are caused by stress and have nothing to do with MS. Some women with MS may even suffer from other symptoms such as joint pain or rashes that get worse during menstruation. In general, it's best to avoid eating foods high in sugar or refined carbohydrates throughout your period so you won't gain weight due to your monthly cycle. If you feel an increase in fatigue and/or headaches in your periods, take steps to help manage your symptoms. Try using the following tips if you notice any signs of worsening MS symptoms: • Reduce the amount of caffeine you consume. This helps prevent weight gain through dehydration. • Limit alcohol intake. Drinking too much may worsen conditions associated with MS, including headaches. • Avoid spicy foods. You might find this helps relieve symptoms of MS. • Choose healthy food options, especially vegetables and fruits. Foods like dark leafy green vegetables, nuts, seeds, fruit, legumes, beans and soy products are good choices for people with MS. Many research studies suggest that consuming more fiber, folate, potassium, magnesium, and vitamin B12 can improve symptoms such as hot flashes and night sweats. However, there isn't evidence to support dietary recommendations based on specific nutritional needs for people with MS. To learn more about the benefits of eating a variety of nutritious foods, see our article on how to eat better with MS. Question: What diseases do I need to pay attention to when considering treatment for my MS? Complete Answer: It depends upon which disease you're interested in treating. Many treatments can benefit both types of MS, some will work better for severe cases. Generally, however, if you suspect a diagnosis of MS, you should start treatment right away. After deciding what approach to use, make sure you consider all of the risks and possible complications involved. Questions About MS Treatment If you

Pregnancies, Later Menopause Tied to Progressive MS Onset Age — Pregnancies may have a dose effect on delaying progressive MS by , Senior Staff Writer, MedPage Today Women with multiple sclerosis (MS) who had never given birth and those who began menopause prematurely developed progressive MS earlier, a single-center observational analysis suggested. Nulliparous women experienced progressive MS onset at a mean age of 41.9, while women with one or more full-term pregnancies had progressive MS onset at a mean age of 47.1 (=0.069), reported Burcu Zeydan, MD, of the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minnesota, and colleagues. Pregnancies appeared to have a dose effect on delaying progressive MS onset. Women with a history of one to three full pregnancies had progressive MS at a mean age of 46.4, while those with four or more pregnancies had progressive MS at a mean age of 52.6 (=0.005). Menopause age also was associated with progressive MS onset age (R=0.359, <0.001), Zeydan and colleagues wrote in . The study explores the intricate relationship between sex hormones and MS, Zeydan said. "It is unique because it demonstrates that MS does not impact menopause, but potentially vice versa," she told The findings have potential implications for counseling women with MS about reproductive health, Zeydan added. "For example, women with MS who are questioning a pregnancy decision may now consider that a higher number of pregnancies are actually associated with a delay in progressive MS onset," she said. "Similarly, prevention of early menopause, such as avoiding oophorectomy, may help delay progressive MS onset and prevent long-term disability accumulation." Numerous reports, including a 1998 , have shown that women have a reduced risk of relapse during pregnancy followed by an increased risk of disease reactivation after delivery. How MS is related to longer-term outcomes like disease progression is less clear, however. In this analysis, Zeydan and colleagues looked at survey data from 137 postmenopausal MS patients seen at the Mayo Clinic, and records of 396 age-matched controls without MS, from the Mayo Clinic Cohort Study of Oophorectomy and Aging-2, a population-based cohort in Olmsted, Minnesota. MS patients were a median age of 62.6, and survey data were cross-checked against Mayo Clinic medical records. Menopause type was classified as natural or non-natural, which included women who went into menopause due to surgical intervention or chemotherapy/radiotherapy. Menopause at age 45 or younger was considered premature/early. Progressive MS was defined as an insidious, irreversible worsening of neurological symptoms due to MS lasting for 1 year or more. Menarche age was similar between MS patients and controls (=0.306). Women with MS had fewer full-term pregnancies than the controls (<0.001). Non-natural menopause was more common in MS patients (40.7%) than in controls (30.1%, =0.030). Median age at natural menopause was similar between groups (age 50 for MS patients; 51 for controls). Time from onset of MS relapses to onset of progressive MS was shorter for women with premature/early menopause (mean 12.9 years) than for women with normal menopause (mean 17.8 years). Age at menopause also was associated with age at reaching severe disability, defined as an

Complementary & Alternative Medicines Find Programs & Services in Your Area COVID-19 Vaccine Guidance for People Living with MS MS is three times and is in women of childbearing age than in any other age group. Many women report their MS symptoms fluctuate during their menstrual cycle and at menopause. The risks of taking an oral contraception pill (OPC) is no different for a woman with MS than it is for a woman who does not have MS. There is no evidence the OCPs reduce the effectiveness of DMTs. Conversely, there is no evidence that DMTs reduce the effectiveness of OCPs (). However, some medications used to treat MS symptoms interact with OPCs. Be sure to tell your MS healthcare provider and your gynecologic care provider of all the medications and supplements you are taking to ensure there are no interactions. Many women report that their MS symptoms temporarily worsen around the time of their period. A few studies have confirmed this and others have shown that women on oral contraception have less worsening of their MS symptoms prior to the start of their period (; ). These findings have all come from relatively small studies, and more research is needed to fully characterize the relationship between MS and the menstrual cycle. The age of menopause onset does not appear to be affected by MS. Some women experience a worsening of their MS symptoms during menopause. And for some, the hot flashes associated with menopause may intensify or bring on MS symptoms. Menopause may make issues with mood, sleep, fatigue, cognitive problems or bladder function more challenging (Kaisey et al, 2018). You should discuss any new or worsening MS symptoms with your MS healthcare provider. There have not been any large studies of women with MS using hormone replacement therapy (HRT) during menopause. If you have questions, discuss the use of HRT with your gynecologic care provider. Menstrual problems may be associated with several different conditions—including MS; dysthymia; depression or anxiety disorder (MDD); neuroplasticity of the brain/hypothalamus; dyslipidemia; low blood pressure; type 2 diabetes; cardiovascular disease; osteoarthritis; epilepsy."* Cases in which women experience lower levels but higher frequencies than their male counterparts can include "symptom changes that occur as part atypical menstruation," says Dr., Jana Scharpeffer of The College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists' Medical Center for Women's Health Services who was not involved on this study ("Menopausal Symptoms Affecting Multiple Sclerosis"). Because there is no known cause(s) of these menstrual abnormalities, it would appear very unlikely from an epidemiological perspective they were caused by abnormal sex hormones during ovulation alone.[15] In fact many studies have shown significant differences between nonmenorrhoea patients treated using estrogen rather then progestin against other diseases such overgrowth issues,[16][17];[18], although more research needs take place before definitive conclusions regarding causality could emerge."[19]. It has also been suggested that certain autoimmune disorders including lupus erythematoskeletal syndrome might lead people toward poor fertility without any specific risk factors being considered when considering potential interventions:[20],[21]"This paper presents evidence supporting differential treatment strategies among subclinical Lymphoma sufferers compared favorably towards those whose history indicates normal infertility rates" according Tochberg et al.(citation needed.) ©2018 WebMD, Inc. All rights reserved. eMedicineHealth does not provide medical advice, diagnosis or treatment. What Is Multiple Sclerosis? MS Symptoms, Causes, Diagnosis Reviewed By: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disease in which the body's immune system attacks its own central nervous system (the brain and spinal cord). In MS, the immune system attacks and damages or destroys myelin, a substance that surrounds and insulates the nerves. The myelin destruction causes a distortion or interruption in nerve impulses traveling to and from the brain. This can result in a wide variety of symptoms. Multiple sclerosis is estimated to affect 2.8 million people worldwide. Most people are diagnosed between the ages of 20 and 50, though it can also occur in young children and the elderly. Multiple sclerosis is three times more common in women than in men. In addition, nearly all women afflicted with MS get the condition before menopause. This could mean that hormones play an important role in the disease’s development. Usually, MS in men is more severe than it is in women. They typically get MS in their 30s and 40s, just as their testosterone levels begin to decline. Although MS is more common in women than men overall, one form of the disease contradicts this pattern. People with primary progressive (PP) MS are about as likely to be male as female. (The four main types of MS are described later). People who smoke are more likely to develop MS, and to develop it more severely and with a faster progression. MS is more prevalent among Caucasians than other ethnicities. MS is believed to have a genetic component as people with a first-degree relative with the disease have a higher incidence than the general population. We don't know exactly what causes multiple sclerosis, but it is believed to be some combination of immunologic, environmental, infectious, and/or genetic factors. Some theories have been proposed, though there is not enough evidence to establish any one cause. Theories as to what causes MS include: Exposure to chemical solvents such as amines, esters, ethers, and ketones Viruses such as Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) and human herpes virus 6 (HHV-6) Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disorder in which the immune system mistakenly perceives its own myelin (the protective sheath around the nerves) as an intruder and attacks it, as it would a virus or other foreign infectious agent. To understand how this harms the body, it helps to understand how nerves work. A nerve can be seen by the naked eye, but it is made up of hundreds or even thousands of microscopic nerve fibers wrapped by connective tissue. Nerves conduct messages to and from the brain by way of electrical impulses. Often the nerve fibers that make up a nerve are all individually wrapped in myelin, a protective sheath that causes electric impulses to conduct down the nerve much faster than fibers that lack myelin. (The same principle is used to improve electric wires by covering them with a plastic outer layer.) In multiple sclerosis, the immune system's T cells attack the

Medically reviewed by — — is a progressive, immune-mediated disorder. That means the system designed to keep your body healthy mistakenly attacks parts of your body that are vital to everyday function. The protective coverings of nerve cells are damaged, which leads to diminished function in the brain and spinal cord. is a disease with unpredictable symptoms that can vary in intensity. While some people experience fatigue and numbness, severe cases of MS can cause , vision loss, and diminished brain function. Common early signs of multiple sclerosis (MS) include: Visual problems are one of the most common symptoms of MS. Inflammation affects the optic nerve and disrupts central vision. This can cause , , or loss of vision. You may not notice the vision problems immediately, as degeneration of clear vision can be slow. Pain when you look up or to one side also can accompany vision loss. There are variety of with MS-related vision changes. MS affects nerves in the brain and spinal cord (the body’s message center). This means it can send conflicting signals around the body. Sometimes, no signals are sent. This results in . Tingling sensations and numbness are one of the most common warning signs of MS. Common sites of numbness include the face, arms, legs, and fingers. Chronic pain and involuntary muscle spasmsare also common with MS. One study, according to the , showed that half of people with MS had chronic pain. or spasms () are also common. You might experience stiff muscles or joints as well as uncontrollable, painful jerking movements of the extremities. The legs are most often affected, but back pain is also common. Unexplained fatigue and weaknessaffect about in the early stages of MS. occurs when nerves deteriorate in the spinal column. Usually, the fatigue appears suddenly and lasts for weeks before improving. The weakness is most noticeable in the legs at first. Dizziness and problems with coordination and balance can decrease the mobility of someone with MS. Your doctor may refer to these as problems with your gait. People with MS often feel lightheaded, dizzy, or as if their surroundings are spinning (). This symptom often occurs when you stand up. A dysfunctional bladder is another symptom occurring in up to of people with MS. This can include , strong urges to urinate, or . Urinary-related symptoms are often manageable. Less often, people with MS experience , , or . Sexual arousal can also be a problem for people with MS because it begins in the central nervous system — where MS attacks. About half of people with MS will develop some kind of issue with their cognitivefunction. This can include: and other emotional health problems are also common. Major depression is common among people with MS. The stresses of MS can also cause , , and a condition called . This involves bouts of uncontrollable crying and laughing. Coping with MS symptoms, along with relationship or family issues, can make depression and other emotional disorders even more challenging. Not everyone with MS will have the same symptoms.
